solution.tex: Let $f$ be the function \[f(z)=\frac{e^{iaz}}{1+z^2}=\frac{\cos(az)+i\sin(az)}{1+z^2}.\] If $z\in\mathbb{R}$, then this is mostly what we are looking for. That is, \[\int_\mathbb{R}f(z)dz=\int_{-\infty}^\infty\frac{\cos(ax)}{1+x^2}+i\frac{\sin(ax)}{1+x^2}dx.\] Moreover, $\sin(ax)$ is an odd function and $\cos(ax)$ is an even function. Thus \[\int_0^\infty\frac{\cos(ax)}{1+x^2}dx=\frac{1}{2}\int_\mathbb{R}f(z)dz.\] To find this, let's instead try to solve $\int_\gamma f(z)dz$ where $\gamma$ is the boundary of the upper half disc of radius $R$ centered at the origin. $f$ is a meromorphic function on $\mathbb{C}$ with poles only at $\pm i$. As long as $R>1$, Cauchy's integral formula tells us that \[\int_\gamma f(z)dz=\int_\gamma\frac{e^{iaz}/(z+i)}{z-i}dz=2\pi ie^{ai^2}/(i+i)=\pi e^{-a}.\] Now we just need to estimate the arc portion of $\gamma$. Let $p$ be the curved portion of $\gamma$. Then $p(t)=Re^{it}$ for $t\in[0,\pi]$. An estimate for $f\circ p(t)$ is \[|f(p(t))|=\left|\frac{1}{1+R^2e^{2it}}e^{iaRe^{it}}\right|\leq\frac{1}{R^2-1}\left|e^{iaR(\cos(t)+i\sin(t)}\right|\] \[=\frac{1}{R^2-1}\left|e^{-aR\sin(t)+iaR\cos(t)}\right|=\frac{1}{R^2-1}e^{-aR\sin(t)}.\] Because $0\leq t\leq\pi$, we know that $\sin(t)$ is nonnegative. Then $-aR\sin(t)\leq0$, so $e^{-aR\sin(t)}\leq1$. Thus, on $p$, \[|f(p(t))|\leq\frac{1}{R^2-1}.\] Then the integral is bounded by \[\left|\int_pf(z)dz\right|\leq\int_p|f(z)||dz|=\int_0^\pi|f(p(t))|Rdt\leq\int_0^\pi\frac{1}{R^2-1}Rdt=\frac{R\pi}{R^2-1}\to0.\] That is, the contribution from $p$ vanishes as $R\to\infty$. Thus \[2\int_0^\infty\frac{\cos(ax)}{1+x^2}dx=\int_\mathbb{R}f(z)dz=\lim_{R\to\infty}\int_\gamma f(z)dz=\pi e^{-a}.\] So our answer is $\frac{\pi}{2}e^{-a}.$
